sense.name: move, continue, or travel somewhere
sense.commentary: Syntax Includes: NP1[rider/mover] RIDE (ADVP) (PP[directional]) NP1[agent] RIDE NP2[patient] (ADVP) (PP[directional]) Includes: RIDE AWAY, RIDE HORSEBACK, RIDE OFF
sense.examples: The boy rode on the donkey and the old psychologist walked. We rode the train from Sydney to Perth. She loves to ride her new motorcycle through the town. Others rode to freedom on truks and in cars. Together they mounted the laird's good mare and rode away/off into the night. By 17, Thompson had rode horseback from central New Mexico to Calgary. Let it ride for now. The train rode. The ambassador rode on and on till he came at the very last to the house. They rode on and on.

sense.name: cause to travel or be moved somewhere
sense.commentary: Syntax Is: NP1[agent] RIDE NP2[patient] PP[directional]
sense.examples: I think you'd better ride me over to the hospital. My father put me on his old bicycle and rode me to the wedding banquet. She really rode me to realize my full potential. I am asking myself which devil rode me to plan and push this project. Gambling quickly rode him to poverty.

sense.name: move, travel, or slide along some path, body, state, or support
sense.commentary: Syntax Is: NP1[agent] RIDE NP2[patient] Includes: RIDE UP, RIDE ON Note: Metaphorically (and also literally, in some cases) this sense entails moving along a body for the benefit of something. In case of birds example, the current of air helps themp lift up. In case of Prime Minister example, he benefits from popularity.
sense.examples: In 2003, at a spot on Maui called Jaws, a surfer rode the largest wave so far. In the end we just rode the freeway and enjoyed the 2 meters of lane to ourselves. The inner lining rides up my legs and becomes very uncomfortable if I run in them. The ship rode at a high angle over the crest of the wave and down the other side. The birds will catch the front end of a wave and ride the current of air. The Prime Minister is riding on a wave of popularity. If Mondale can ride a tide of sympathy votes, he might get to keep his job. Ride the boat at a constant 1/4 throttle opening for about 1 minute.

sense.name: RIDE ON-be contingent on success or viability of something
sense.commentary: Syntax Is: NP1[topic] RIDE ON NP2 Is: RIDE ON
sense.examples: Most of the weight rides on the central shaft. The future of the company now rides on the new managing director. I have a lot of money riding on that horse. Your grade will ride on your homework, attendance, and participation.

sense.name: RIDE OUT-endure through a trial of endurance
sense.commentary: Syntax Includes: NP1[agent] RIDE OUT NP2[actor] NP1[agent] RIDE OUT NP2[topic]
sense.examples: Many companies did not manage to ride out the recession. The ship managed to ride out the storm.

sense.name: apply pressure, control, or criticism
sense.commentary: Syntax Is: NP1[agent] RIDE NP2[patient] (PP) Includes: RIDE THE HERD ON
sense.examples: Don't rest foot on clutch pedal while driving or ride the clutch for long periods. I have promised not to ride him so hard in my responses to his posts. Your boss is riding you much too hard at the moment. He was riding me about my English grammar constantly. Adams wanted the national bank to ride the herd on issuing too many notes.

sense.name: (cause to) anchor in a particular place
sense.examples: The ship rode at anchor in Eniwetok until 17 July when she returned to sea. The moon rode high in the night sky.

sense.name: function in a particular manner when moving
sense.examples: By 1600, the weather was improving and the ship rode better. This new model supposed to ride well over rough terrain. My new truck rides smoothly.

sense.name: drive horse or cattle while accompanying them
sense.examples: These weeks are spent riding the herd and moving cattle to fresh grass and water.

sense.name: RIDE ROUGHSHOD OVER-treat harshly without consideration
sense.examples: They accused the government of riding roughshod over parliamentary procedure. Insurance companies have rode roughshod over what doctors could prescribe for patients.

sense.name: RIDE BENCH-be out of the game
sense.examples: She played in 24 games and rode the bench completely for seven.
